meta.title: Algorithms & Complexity Questions (formatted for LLM)
meta.author: user
meta.notes: All constants (b, c, d) are positive where stated. Preserve option labels. Use this JSON as input to an LLM solver.

questions.statement:
For positive constants b, c, and d, consider the recurrence relation:
T(n) = b, if n = 0
T(n) = b, if n = 1
T(n) = T(n-2) + c * n^2 + d, if n > 1
Which of the following statements is TRUE?

given.recurrence: T(n) = T(n-2) + c * n^2 + d  for n>1; base cases T(0)=b, T(1)=b

questions.task: Determine the asymptotic growth of T(n) and select the correct option.

options.label: d
options.text: T(n) = O(n * n * log n * log n)

questions.statement: The Quickselect algorithm can be run in worst-case time complexity O(N), provided we have an O(N) algorithm to find a median. In your own words, justify why Quickselect using the median of medians algorithm to pick the pivots can still achieve worst-case time complexity O(N).

given.assumption: There exists an O(N) median-finding subroutine (median-of-medians).

questions.task: Provide a clear, self-contained justification (in your own words) that Quickselect with median-of-medians achieves worst-case O(N) time.

questions.topic: Sorting algorithm with binary search insertion
questions.statement:
Consider this sorting algorithm:
1: function SORT(A[1..n])
2: for i = 2 to n do
3:     Set key = A[i]
4:     Binary search to find max k < i such that A[k] ≤ key
5:     for j = i downto k + 1 do
6:         A[j] = A[j-1]
7:     A[k+1] = key
Select all the correct statements about this algorithm.

given.algorithm_description: Insertion sort variant that uses binary search to locate the insertion position then shifts elements to insert key.

options.label: a
options.text: The worst-case number of comparisons is O(n).

options.label: b
options.text: The worst-case number of comparisons is O(n log n).

options.label: c
options.text: The worst-case number of comparisons is O(n^2).

options.label: d
options.text: The worst-case time complexity is O(n).

options.label: e
options.text: The worst-case time complexity is O(n log n).

options.label: f
options.text: The worst-case time complexity is O(n^2).

questions.task: Choose all correct options and justify each choice briefly (count comparisons vs. total time considering shifts).

questions.statement:
There are n elements v1, v2, ..., vn and a distance function dist that is a metric (dist(v_i, v_i)=0, positivity: dist(v_i,v_j)>0 for i≠j, symmetry). For a value 1 < k < n, we want to partition the elements into k non-empty clusters C1, C2, ..., Ck so that the minimum distance between any pair of elements assigned to distinct clusters is as large as possible.
Describe a method with time complexity O(n ? log n) for finding an optimal solution and justify why it works.

given.goal: maximize the minimum inter-cluster distance (i.e., find clustering that maximizes the minimum distance between points in different clusters)

questions.task: Describe an algorithm that finds an optimal clustering and has time complexity of the form O(n^? log n). Explain why it is correct and why the runtime holds.
hints: Think about constructing a minimum spanning tree (MST) of the complete graph where edge weights are distances and then cutting the (k-1) largest edges to form k clusters.
Compute MST using Kruskal's or Prim's algorithm, then remove (k-1) largest edges.

questions.statement: What is the number of distinct, valid two colourings of the following undirected graph?

usage_instructions: Feed each question object to the LLM solver. For MCQ items supply 'choices' and brief 'justifications'. For open-response items return clear, step-by-step explanations and any recurrences solved symbolically. Use LaTeX in explanation strings where helpful.
